Grant Support Strategy: Network-building and collaboration; Policy, advocacy and systems reform; Research; Program support; Curriculum development
Grant Description: This grant will support the Massachusetts Afterschool Partnership to create a program that will become a national model to increase literacy proficiency for Latino English language learner students. Specifically, the Massachusetts Afterschool Partnership will: 1) create a literacy curriculum for use in afterschool and summer; 2) develop national policy recommendations for English language learner students; 3) conduct a data-driven analysis of the program model; and 4) design and promote a national best practices model. The overall goal of this project is to help close the educational achievement gap between lower-income English language learner students and higher-income English speaking peers

Grant Description: The Greenlight Fund seeks to transform the lives of children, youth, and families in high-poverty urban areas by creating local infrastructure and a consistent annual process to (a) identify critical community needs; (B) import innovative, entrepreneurial programs that can have significant, measureable impact; and (C) galvanize local support to help programs reach and sustain impact in the cities it serves. Greenlight operates in Boston (where it was founded), Cincinnati, Philadelphia, and the San Francisco Bay Area. This Serving Bay Area Communities grant will support Greenlights second fund in the Bay Area. In each Greenlight community, a local executive director organizes a local Selection Advisory Council to select each grantee.

Grant Description: To support Transforming Justice: The Center for Mindfulness and Criminal Justice, a project of the Prison Dharma Network, Inc. Transforming Justice (TJ) works to address the brutality, racial bias, and inhumanity that pervades the criminal justice system, and seeks to transform criminal justice institutions through mindfulness-based practices and principles. TJ'S primary strategy is to work with criminal justice professionals, training them in mindfulness-based skills that help them cope with the mental, emotional, and physical toll of their work, while also shaping their behavior and decision-making in a way that fosters greater fairness, compassion, and respect for the dignity of all those they encounter. Major programs include establishing mindfulness as an important skill for attorneys and judges, building a national movement for mindfulness in criminal justice, and the San Jose Project which engages with criminal justice leaders in San Jose to explore how this approach might be implemented throughout an entire jurisdiction.

Grant Population Served: Adults; People of Asian descent; Low-income people
Grant Description: This grant increase is one of ten tie-off grants to state organizations participating in the State Priorities Partnership (formerly the State Fiscal Analysis Initiative). The Ford, Annie E. Casey, and Mott foundations created the initiative in 1992 in order to build state capacity for timely, credible, and accessible tax and budget policy analyses on behalf of low- and moderate-income families. Massachusetts Budget and Policy Center joined this effort in 1993 and has become recognized as an authoritative source of information and analysis. This grant increase will support the grantee's ongoing analytical, communications, and coalition building efforts, with a particular emphasis on education issues.

Grant Recipient Name: Family Health Center Of Worcester Inc
Grant Population Served: People with diseases and illnesses
Grant Description: Please provide a brief description of the proposed projecamily Health Center of Worcester is working to complete a $9.13 Million capital campaign to improve access to care for low income residents, and to upgrade our facilities. The project will fund the physical expansion and renovation of our main administrative, clinical, and teaching site at 26 Queen Street, Worcester. This expansion and renovation will allow FHCW to meet the significant increase in demand for primary care, vision care, pharmacy, and dental services for approximately 7,000 new patients. Construction completed to-date to add 18,000 S.F. On th ground floor of the building has provided a fourth primary care team with 20 exam rooms which opened in 12/2013 to provide an estimated 4,835 new patients with access to a primary care medical home; 4 new dental operatories on the third floor, bringing the total to 14, to address the overwhelming demand for urgent/emergency dental treatment and preventive care; a new vision/optical service in partnership with the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy & Health Sciences (MCPHS) which opened in 5/2014 to provide eye care for low income,to accommodate 22% increase in our patient population. Family Health Center of Worcester currently provides services for over 33,000 area residents. Phase 2 of the project includes renovations to refresh paint and flooring in 56,000 square feet of existing health center clinical and teaching space to update and repair the facility; construct new nurses stations on 3 existing clinical teams to allow more efficient workflow and consistent work spaces; renovate two storage spaces to convert to office space for improved patient confidentiality in HIV counseling and testing, and health education; and replace aged equipment in disrepair throughout the health center to assure sustainability of operations well into the future.

Grant Description: To identify ACA as a more ethnically, racially, geographically, culturally, economically and socially diverse organization. Our Artreach initiative allows us to attract a greater audience base to the ACA by offering performances, classes and workshops for everyone. We are in an area that is easily accessible by public transportation and parking is plentiful and free. We aim to serve over 8,500 people w/ free programming and wish to increase access to art programming throughout the Center by 20% and offer additional opportunities for outreach. We will measure growth through attendance and enrollment numbers captured at check-in at the events.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: Girls; Students
Grant Support Strategy: Capacity-building and technical assistance; Program support
Grant Description: Latino Education Institute at Worcester State University (LEI), Worcester Youth Center (WYC) and The Community Builders Inc. At Plumley Village (TCB) are pleased to submit this proposal for enhancement and implementation of our One Circle program for middle school aged girls in Worcester. Since our initial work with FHD in 2011, we have participated in the community planning process initiated by the Investing In Girls Alliance (IIGA) and subsequently by the WISH Task Force. We are aligned with WISHs strategic plan and specifically goal two, to improve quality sexual health education. We propose a three-year plan for implementation of a culturally responsive gender specific program to support healthy relationships and build positive futures for Worcesters middle school girls. Our program is built on the Girls Circle model and enhanced to address the unique needs of the girls served by our diverse organizations. The framework is a gender specific afterschool program for 7TH & 8TH grade girls; running 4 hours a week throughout with the school year. Each partner site will engage a total of 135 girls over three years. In addition, 100 families will participate in family academies. The program will provide programming at each site, joint activities across all sites and family engagement activities throughout the year. Topics include: Identity and Culture- self-expression and positive cultural identity, Healthy Relationships –healthy romantic relationships, human sexuality, and self confidence, Leadership- developing leadership, team building, and career exploration. A capstone project will engage girls in a multimedia campaign to promote healthy lives and healthy choices. Family Academies support family learning and discussion aligned with the three core topics. Year one will include a planning and outreach component for the first three months and a year program pilot to ensure our program is solidly built on the unique needs of our target populations.

Grant Funder Name: The Morris and Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation
Grant Population Served: People of African descent; Low-income people
Grant Support Strategy: Policy, advocacy and systems reform; Program support
Grant Description: The funding requested from the Morris & Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation will provide general support for ECO City Farms for our full range of food justice work. ECO City Farms serves the low income and working class, largely Black and Latino populations of inner Capital Beltway communities, particularly the Port Towns municipalities of Bladensburg, Colmar Manor, Cottage City and Edmonston in Prince George's County and near-in Washington, DC. ECO creates greater access to and knowledge about healthy food in these communities. All of the USDA-certified food deserts inside the Beltway are in Prince George's County. Many neighborhoods lack an adequately stocked grocery within a mile's radius of their homes, and many county families rely instead on highly processed meals, often saturated with transfats, salt and sugar. The county's Planning Department documents that 71% of all county restaurants are fast food, and the Maryland State Department of Mental Health notes that in Prince George's County, 71.4% Of adults are overweight/obese and childhood obesity figures are rising. Diabetes and diet-related illnesses have reached epidemic proportions. In its Urban Agriculture Report, Policy Link says studies consistently show that there are fewer retail outlets selling affordable, nutritious food in low-income communities than in wealthier ones, and fewer in predominantly African American and Latino neighborhoods than in predominantly white neighborhoods. However, they also report that residents with greater access to fresh produce consume healthier diets and have lower rates of diet-related diseases than their counterparts in neighborhoods lacking food access. Unless area residents are able to access more healthy food and become more conscious of what and how they eat, the already alarming rates of obesity, chronic illness and early death will continue to rise. ECO not only built and maintains two urban farms in the county, we also make healthy food affordable and accessible in a variety of ways, and teach residents how to farm and garden, prepare nutritious food for their families and to live healthy lives in greater harmony with nature. In 2015, approximately 5,000 individuals were served by ECO through its CSA, Farmer's Market sales, Community Nutrition Education and Community College courses, Summer Youth Programs, community events and outreach activities. In the coming year, an anticipated 7,000 individuals will be served by ECO's work.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: Students
Grant Description: Youthconnect Worcester’s mission is to provide high quality neighborhood-based recreational, educational and cultural activities to isolated and underserved Worcester youth for middle school age youth. The goal of Youthconnect is to establish a seamless, inclusive youth-serving system; a consortium modeled on best practices and built on a framework that delivers positive outcomes for health, education, and family stability to youth in Worcester’s highest need neighborhoods. Youthconnect emerged from the very successful Youthnet collaboration providing culturally competent developmental summer programs to Worcester's middle school youth for 20 years. Partners include: Boys & Girls Club of Worcester, Friendly House, Girls Inc. Of Worcester, YMCA of Central MA, Y.O.U. Inc., YWCA of Central MA, The Nativity School, The HOPE Coalition and Worcester Youth Center. These partners share a commitment to provide year round youth development opportunities to youth who reside in Worcester’s highest environments. The Summer of 2016 program will operate tentatively June 27 through August 12. Each weeknight, one recreational facility per team will be open, 5:30PM - 9:30PM for a host of activities, subject to facility availability. Activities typically include: aerobics, arts and crafts, basketball, cooking, games, movies, swimming, volleyball, etc. More structured activities, including basketball tournaments will be determined after the first few weeks of operation. For Youthnet to maximize its effect and service the cities youth who are most at risk, we recognize the need for full time staff to be out in the community during the afternoon hours developing relationships and building trust with our youth. Each afternoon the Team Leader and 2 full time staff will be out in there target neighborhoods from 2PM to 4PM recruitment and conducting neighborhood based programs.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: Children and youth
Grant Description: Nativity School of Worcester respectfully requests a scholarship grant of $10,000 for a fifth-grade Nativity Worcester student. The request represents the costs associated with one student to engage in a comprehensive education at Nativity Worcester during one year. Funding from the Fred Harris Daniels Foundation will directly benefit a school which has become a beacon of hope for Worcester’s at-risk population. This grant would represent an investment in the future of Worcester’s underprivileged students. The Nativity School of Worcester education aims to inspire and aid each student to achieve a college degree and provide his family with a financially stable future. This scholarship will give one student access to: inspiring educators who will guide the boys through four years of rigorous academic programming; all of the textbooks and literature needed for a cutting-edge, dynamic curriculum; current technology in all forms, including desktop computers, laptops, and tablets; equipment and facilities for varied competitive team sports and intramurals during each season; an arts program with depth and scope, including drama, drawing and music; and a support network for graduates that will help them gain admittance to a private high school.

Grant Population Served: Ethnic and racial groups; Low-income people; People with disabilities; People with HIV/AIDS
Grant Description: Through our Nutrition Program for Individuals and Families Living with Critical Illnesses in Worcester, we will deliver 28,000 medically-tailored meals to the doorsteps of 90 low-income individuals and families affected by a critical illness and provide these clients with 135 hours of nutrition education and counseling. Each week Community Servings will deliver 5 days worth of customized, nutritionally-packed lunches, dinners, and snacks to the door-steps of our critically ill clients, their dependents and caregivers who live in Worcester. Each client's meals are tailored by our Registered Dietitian, in consultation with clients and their healthcare provider, to offer specialized nutrition care -- the correct balance of nutrients and calories to help the client to combat a specific disease, gain or maintain weight and muscle mass, and manage the effects of drugs and other powerful medical treatments.

Grant Support Strategy: Public engagement and education; Policy, advocacy and systems reform; Advocacy; Systems reform; Grassroots organizing; Equal access
Grant Description: The Girls’ Leadership Institute (GLI) has as its mission to teach girls the skills to be brave, resilient and connected, equipping girls to create change in the world. GLI began as a single summer camp that expanded into five programs: Summer Camp, Parent-daughter Workshops, Professional Development Training, After School, and Day Camp; working in five states: California, Colorado, New York, New Jersey, and Massachusetts. Novo's funding supports a one-day training led by Race Forward that was held in March 2016. The training and consultation helped GLI develop a shared language on racial and social justice; an understanding of the structural and institutional racism that we swim in daily in US culture; and helped them develop a framework for further conversations within the organization.

Children and youth; LGBTQ people; Students
Grant Description: For support for the LGBTQ Youth Leadership Development Project. Support for this project will ensure that History Unerased (HUE) offers internship opportunities for young people that create new leaders and contributors to the evolving work toward LGBTQ equality. HUE interns will be directly involved within each arm of HUE’s programs and services, including: working directly with the National Park Service LGBT Heritage Commission for the nomination of Concord Academy as a registered historic landmark, expanding HUE’s social media presence to appeal more directly to youth, and assisting in the development of complementing materials associated with the Give Voice to History project with Eric Marcus. Building a strong infrastructure, which includes salaries for interns, development of groundbreaking products and trainings, as well as consulting with Queer Studies scholars, enables the flexibility needed for HUE’s organizational success. Employing young interns will ensure that this vital history and its intersections with other marginalized histories reach as many youth as possible, and that our youth have opportunities to play a vital leadership role in the process of linking social justice and educational materials for the K-12 context. One in five LGBTQ youth of color will attempt suicide; 45% of all homeless youth identify as LGBTQ; LGBTQ youth are 30% more likely to drop out of school and 60% more likely to skip school. The invisibility of LGBTQ history, people and content within our nation’s schools significantly contributes to these staggering statistics. GLSEN reports that positive lessons about LGBTQ people can mitigate this crisis dramatically. Including the stories and voices of all people, especially those who have been historically marginalized, is a direct path to social justice, equity and agency.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: Children and youth; People of African descent; Immigrants; Refugees and displaced people; Students
Grant Support Strategy: Faculty and staff development; Outreach; Program support
Grant Description: The African Community Education Program is requesting funding from the Fred Harris Daniels Foundation to help support our Family Education & Outreach Program. This program provides adult English and U.S. Citizenship classes, an Early Literacy Playgroup, guided parent-child literacy activities, and family outreach support services to African refugee and immigrant families in Worcester, MA. The need for English literacy is significant among the African population in the City of Worcester, with nearly 1,000 African refugees being resettled here between FY2006 to FY2014, and new families continuing to arrive. Overall, the population of African-born residents in Worcester is estimated at 7,973. We will provide Family Education programming on Saturday mornings from 9:00 A.M. To 1:30 P.M. From October 2016 through June 2017, for a total of 32 sessions. We will provide wraparound outreach support to families on a year-round basis. We developed this program with the support of the Daniels Foundation, and have created partnerships with Worcester Public Schools’ Adult Learning Center and the Worcester Family Partnership to provide free teachers and build sustainability into the program. With your continued support, we will be able to continue to provide services to 18 adults and 25 youth. Specifically, funds from Daniels would support hours for our Family Education & Outreach Coordinator to coordinate the adult classes, playgroup and literacy activities; hours for the Citizenship Teacher and program support staff; and hours for 4 Outreach Workers to provide wraparound support to families.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: At-risk youth
Grant Description: Worcester Youth Center (WYC) requests $5,000 in overall support of its programs and operations. Founded in 1994, the Center has evolved from a drop-in center for young adults and adolescents in Worcester to a center with much greater capacity, serving more youth and offering a wider variety of programs and transitional support activities promoting positive youth development. The Youth Center has a host of activities in which young people can get involved. The youth can choose to enroll in more than one activity and attend year round. Or, they can obtain discreet support either one time or periodically throughout the year. Activities are grouped into four programs: Academic Support, Creative Expression & Leadership, Health/Wellness, and Work Preparation. We are requesting support to help fund the operations of the Center so that we can continue to provide the core programs that fulfill our mission. Most of our contracts do not cover the cost of operating our facility and most often do not allow for more than 5-10% for overhead. All the funds requested are for necessary services that allow the WYC to function. Failure to fund these operations compromises our programs which impacts the youth we serve.

Grant Funder Name: The Fred Harris Daniels Foundation, Inc.
Grant Population Served: Adolescents; Low-income people; Students
Grant Description: In 2015-2016, Bottom Line will continue its growth trajectory and expand to serve about 530 low-income and first-generation high school and college students from Worcester. Access Program: Bottom Line is working with 130 students in their senior year of high school to help them navigate every step of the college application process. Counselors typically help students in five areas: generating a list of colleges suited to students’ academic and financial situations, writing essays, completing applications, securing financial aid, and making a college choice. Working with a caseload of approximately 60 students, counselors build a strong relationship with each student during regularly scheduled one-hour meetings. Success Program: After our Access students make their college decisions, we invite those who choose to attend one of 24 “target” colleges in Massachusetts to join our Success Program. For the first time, in 2015-2016 we will also welcome a handful of rising college freshmen from Worcester into the Success Program who did not received our support applying to college. We have pioneered this innovation, which we call Success Direct, in Boston and New York and are excited to bring it to Worcester. Once students arrive on campus, Bottom Line counselors continue to work one-on-one and in-person with a caseload of 80 to 90 students. Using our codified curriculum, counselors offer regular support in the four areas most likely to cause a student to drop out of college: Degree, Employability, (financial) Aid, and Life, or DEAL. Once students enter the junior year of college they are assigned a career counselor who continues to use the DEAL model but with a heightened focus on a career curriculum designed to make sure they are prepared for the workforce upon graduation. Services include assessing career paths, writing resumes and cover letters, networking skills, securing internships, and finding jobs.
